Package org.bluezoo.gonzalez

package org.bluezoo.gonzalez
Gonzalez: A non-blocking, streaming XML parser for event-driven I/O.

Overview

Gonzalez is a data-driven XML parser that uses a push model instead of the traditional pull model used by SAX parsers. Unlike SAX parsers that pull data from an InputSource, Gonzalez allows you to push data to the parser as it arrives, making it ideal for integration with non-blocking I/O frameworks such as Java NIO selectors, Gumdrop, Netty, or other async pipelines.

Key Features

  • Non-blocking: Processes available data and returns control immediately; never waits for more data
  • Streaming: Handles documents of unlimited size with bounded memory usage
  • SAX2-compatible: Generates standard SAX events via ContentHandler
  • ByteBuffer-based: Uses Java NIO buffers for efficient I/O
  • Automatic charset detection: Handles BOM and XML declaration encoding
  • Full XML 1.0/1.1 support: Including DTD, namespaces, and entity expansion
  • 100% conformant to W3C XML Conformance Test Suite
  • Fast: Can achieve 4.5Ã— the speed of the default Java SAX parser for small documents

Streaming Usage (Non-blocking)

For non-blocking scenarios where data arrives in chunks (e.g., from a network socket or other NIO channel), use the receive() and close() methods. This is the native and preferred method for which Gonzalez was designed. 


 import org.bluezoo.gonzalez.Parser;
 import java.nio.ByteBuffer;

 Parser parser = new Parser();
 parser.setContentHandler(myContentHandler);

 // Optional: set document identifiers for error reporting
 parser.setSystemId("http://example.com/document.xml");
 parser.setPublicId("-//Example//DTD Example 1.0//EN");

 // Feed data as it arrives from network/channel
 while (channel.read(buffer) > 0) {
     buffer.flip();
     parser.receive(buffer);
     buffer.clear();
 }

 // Signal end of document
 parser.close();

NIO Server Integration

Gonzalez is designed to integrate seamlessly with NIO selector-based servers. The parser processes whatever data is available, fires SAX events for complete tokens, and returns control immediately. Incomplete tokens are buffered internally until the next receive() call. 


 // In your selector loop, when data is ready:
 SocketChannel channel = (SocketChannel) key.channel();
 Parser parser = (Parser) key.attachment();

 ByteBuffer buffer = ByteBuffer.allocate(8192);
 int bytesRead = channel.read(buffer);

 if (bytesRead > 0) {
     buffer.flip();
     parser.receive(buffer);
 } else if (bytesRead == -1) {
     parser.close();  // End of stream
 }

Handler Configuration

Gonzalez supports the standard SAX2 handlers:

  • ContentHandler - Element and character events
  • DTDHandler - Notation and unparsed entity declarations
  • ErrorHandler - Error and warning handling
  • EntityResolver - External entity resolution

And SAX2 extension handlers:

  • LexicalHandler - Comments, CDATA sections, entity boundaries
  • DeclHandler - DTD declaration events
  • EntityResolver2 - Enhanced entity resolution
  • Locator2 - Enhanced location information including encoding

SAX2 XMLReader interface

Although designed to operate in non-blocking mode, Gonzalez additionally supports a convenience parse(InputSource) method and implements SAX2 XMLReader for applications that cannot be adapted to an event-driven pipeline.

Note that this will block the calling thread until the entire InputStream is consumed. 


 Parser parser = new Parser();
 parser.setContentHandler(handler);

 // Parse a legacy InputStream
 parser.parse(new InputSource(stream));

Parser Reuse

A single Parser instance can be reused for multiple documents by calling reset() between parses: 


 Parser parser = new Parser();
 parser.setContentHandler(handler);

 // Parse first document stream
 parser.receive(stream1chunk1);
 parser.receive(stream1chunk2);
 parser.receive(stream1chunk3);
 parser.close();

 // Reset and parse another
 parser.reset();
 
 // Parse second documnent stream
 parser.receive(stream2chunk1);
 parser.receive(stream2chunk2);
 parser.close();

Architecture

Internally, Gonzalez uses a pipeline architecture:

  1. ExternalEntityDecoder - Converts bytes to characters with charset detection
  2. Tokenizer - State machine that produces XML tokens
  3. ContentParser - Converts tokens to SAX events
  4. DTDParser - Handles DTD declarations (loaded lazily)
